text: I mean I was just incredibly Muslim
because yeah and he walked in and he
stood then there was a springbok on on
his heart and he know our history rugby
was for the white people in South Africa
predominately the Afrikaners and in the
years of apartheid it became a symbol of
hate and for the black people which you
can understand
we love our sport and innocent African
and I'm a proud Africana it's it's when
you grow up and you you can play with a
rugby the question always is is he good
enough you know do you think he can be a
springbok one day and the years of
apartheid in all the sanctions it hurt
and the core of especially africanus
because sport is a it's a release
mechanism it's something that made us
really proud and when he walked into the
dressing room wearing a springbok on his
on his heart it was just wow and you
just saw a reaction a little bit early
on and I had that reaction you know so
you bite your lip you you you know you
know your teeth and I walked over to him
and he said just actually didn't even
get to him he just said then he said
good luck boys and they turned around
and my number was on his back and that
was me I couldn't sing the anthem
because I knew I would cry I was just so
proud to be a South Africa that day
